In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai rule in the quiet Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a candy potato - known as " nota " locally - directly into the fireplace .

Of course , working late can be dangerous : most of the villagers are unemployed , and many are drinking hard , and there are soldiers here .
No one dares to walk around after 5 p.m. in the village ,  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony , which was admitted in Indonesia in 1969 after a disputed referendum , when only 1,026 elders should vote in front of the occupying forces by public handlift .
An existing movement promoting independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which controls the region and excludes foreign journalists or judicial observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent Papua New Guinea representing the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it is like .
There is no public transport .
The city , with some 19,000 inhabitants , consists of wooden buildings surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated roofs converted by rust into various yellow brown tones .
Very few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and practically no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuan was a god called Uga Tamee .
There were other changes as well .
We were not accustomed to wearing these clothes ,  says Degei and shows her lively , handwoven Turban , her dark shirt and her bright rock .

Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , with 28 % of people living below the poverty line and some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s Goldland .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by the Phoenix Freeport McMoran , is located only 60 miles from Paniai , a high landmine in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
